results.title: 70mm cement splicer
results.material_description: Painted cast iron, stainless steel, rubber
results.brief_description: A film splicer is an essential tool for film editing, enabling the physical joining of film strips. This splicer is designed for cement joins on 70mm film, the largest standard motion picture format. Splicing with cement requires the removal of photographic emulsion from the film end, application of film cement (a solvent-based adhesive) and precise alignment when fusing the two film segments. Cement splices create a strong join along the frame edge and is usually not visible when film is projected.
results.description: A film splicer is an essential tool for film editing, enabling the physical joining of film strips. results.title: Look both ways
results.creator_credit: Sarah Watt, Bridget Ikin, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Hibiscus Films
results.brief_description: Sarah Watt’s feature film “Look both ways” is a highly unusual but most engaging narrative about death, grief and foreboding. Meryl (Justine Clarke), a talented artist who paints greeting cards for a living, she sees death and disaster everywhere she looks. These dire visions are amusingly presented in animated visions of her art work. When Meryl meets Nick there is the hope of romance; but Nick’s is saddled with his own bad news. Around these two, numerous characters swirl with an array of crisis’ to conquer.

results.title: The Blind Man of Siloam lantern slides
The Blind Man of Siloam lantern slides
The Blind Man of Siloam lantern slides
[The Tatler social newsreel]
results.brief_description: This film was one of the many documentaries shot in Victoria by Efftee Studios in the early 30s. In this newsreel compiled and narrated by Peter Newmarch of “The Truth” newspaper and shot by Bert Nicholas, several Melbourne socialites are featured at various functions: a social party in South Yarra, the first official meeting of the Centenary Dog Club at the Melbourne Showground and Ron Cameron’s Riding School. NOTE: No titles included.

results.title: Factory to farm
results.brief_description: Shows the various stages in the manufacture of farm implements and machinery and their use on Australian wheat farms during the 1920s. An important film on Australian history, both from farming and the “Sunshine Harvester Factory” points of view. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Footscray 1911
results.brief_description: Scenes of Footscray around 1911. Shows street scenes, transport, recreation and clothing. Recognizable scenes include Nicholson Street and Forges Store. Footscray Railway Station and Federal Hall.

results.title: A Day at the Ascot Vale School No 2608
results.brief_description: Portrays the outdoor life at a school in the 1920s. Shows school dress, assembly, physical training, organised dancing and games. Junior Red Cross activities, Mothers Club and School Committee.

results.title: Fit For the Future
results.creator_credit: Physical Education Branch, Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: Shows the range of physical education activities provided in Victorian primary schools. Running, jumping, folk dancing, tumbling, team games and swimming are all encouraged so as to develop physical potential.
